summary.title: Computer Networks I

AND.other: A minimum of C- is required in CIS-2025, CIS-2261, or CIS-2271

summary.description: This course introduces the student to network protocols. The course covers physical, data link, network, transport, and application layer protocols. The TCP/IP protocol suite is discussed in detail. Topics include Ethernet, connectionless protocols, connection oriented protocols, and application protocols such as DNS, DHCP, and HTTP. Students learn about both hardware and software troubleshooting tools, security issues, and current topics such as IPv6. Hands-on experience working with networking equipment and use of network simulation tools is used throughout the course.

book.title: Cisco CCNA Routing and Switching ICND2 100-101

course-outcomes.outcome: Be able install and troubleshoot small to medium size Ethernet networks.
Have a working knowledge of networking protocols from the physical layer through the transport layer.
Understand cabling types, connectors, and proper termination.
Be familiar with the use of a network protocol analyzer and be able to analyze network traffic.
Understand the basic fundamentals of WANs.
Have a basic awareness of various networking components including routers switches, hubs and firewalls.
Understand IPv4 addressing concepts, including subnet design, variable length subnet masks and route summarization.
Understand IPv4 services such as Access Control Lists and Network address translation.
Understand IPv6 addressing concepts and subnetting and how to implement IPv6 on hosts and routers.
Be able to operate, troubleshoot, and repair TCP/IP networks.
Understand internetworking protocols such as HTTP, DNS and e-mail related protocols.

course-content.topic: Installing and Operating Ethernet LANs and Switches
Subnet design, VLSM and route summarization

laboratory-studio-outcomes.summary: The laboratories are designed to enhance the student's understanding of the lecture topics. Wherever possible, students get hands-on exposure to equipment referenced in lecture and currently in use in industry. Students learn problem solving and teamwork by overcoming challenges that arise when confronted with real-world situations. Students enhance their technical writing skills by completing a written report on each lab.

laboratory-studio-content.topic: Hands on configuring and operating routing, switching and wireless equipment

outline.room-requirements: CIS laboratory: CON-106 (Randolph Center) or BLP-210 (Williston)
